englishTitle: Fifty earliest English wills in the Court of Probate, London : A. D. 1387-1439 : with a priest's of 1454 / copied and edited from the original registers in Somerset House by Frederick J. Furnivall [electronic resource]

1387. ROBERT CORN. [Citizen of London: gives half his property to himself, to be spent in Masses and Alms; the other half to his son Watkyn and his daughter Katherine; and 40s. to his daughter Genet.  Leaves bequests to St. Mary Abchurch St. Mary Abchurch is in Abchurch Lane in the Ward of Candlewick St.: 'the word. Abchurch , or Upchurch , was added to distinguish this from other Churches of St. Mary , it standing on an Eminence, compared with Houses near it in Thames str. &c .'  It was burnt in the Great Fire of 1666, and rebuilt in 1686.  Hatton's New View of London (1708), ii. 359. , St. Paul's poor folk, Bartholomew New, one of his Executors, &c.] I. Commissary Court of London, Courtney (A.D. 1374-1400), leaf 198, back. In the name of god, Amen, the thorsday Befor the feste of seint laurence, the &yogh;er of the incarnacion of our lord, Millesimo CCC mo lxxxvij, the reyne of the kynge Richard the Secun&dtail; after the conquest the x., I, Robert Corn, Ceteseyn of londo&ntail;, be-quethe my sowle to god, to lygge in the chircℏ of our lady of abbechircℏ. Also y be-quethe my goodes in twey partyes, that ys for [to] seie, half to me, and the tother haluyndel to Watkyn my sone and to Kateryne my Dowter, and also, or my godes be to-partyd, y wi&llbar; that my dettes be payd in alle places that rythful ys.  Also y be-quethe genet my dowter xl. s.  Also to the werkes of our lady of Abbechircℏ xx. s.  Also to the Brethered of our lady of Abbechircℏ xx. s.  Also to eueri prest that ys of this chircℏ, ij. s.  Also to the twey clerkes that bene in the chircℏ. euerich of hem, ij. s.  Also y be-quethe x. s. to the most nedful men & women þat ben in the parche of our lady of abbechircℏ.  Also y be-quethe iij. &lbar;i to 

 bringe me on erthe.  Also y be-quethe Bartilmewe neue the bed of tree, with the cheste atte the foot, weche they haue of myn, & the lauour of peuter with the basyn of led.  Also y wille and ordene þat alle the godes weche y haue be-quethe Katerine, þat it be in kepynge of my too executours, here for to take as sche had ned. Also y be-quethe to the werkes of poulys vj s. viij &dtail;.  And also wat godes þat leuet to-ward me, y wi&llbar; þat it be do of massys and of almes dedys þere most nedful ys.  And here-to I ordeine Watkyn my sone, secutour, & Bartilmewe newe þat oþer; & vp-on this y wi&llbar; þat Bartilmewe neue haue for hys traueal, after þat he seruit. Also y wi&llbar; þat Ioℏn Edmun&dtail; [haue] al þe led þat light in þe stuys, & þe sesterne þat longeþ to the stuys, and þe bordes & þe gaudroun in þe kechyn þat stont in forneys, he to paie þer-for as it ys worthy, for-be ony otherman. (xxij. 129. 199) Probatum fuit presens testamentum coram nobis, Presidente Consistorij londonie, vna cum codicillo eidem annexo, ije Idus Marcij, Anno domini Millesimo CCC mo lxxxixno. Et commissa est administracio omnium bonorum, dictum defunctum & ipsius testamentum concernencium, Waltero Corn, executori in dicto testamento nominato, in forma iuris, & per eundem admissa, Bartholomeo Neue, coexecutore interius in eodem testamento nominato, onus administracionis huiusmodi coram nobis expresse admittere recusante. In cuius rei testimonium, sigillum officialitatis londonie, presentibus duximus apponendum.  Datum Londonie, Die & anno Domini supradictis.
text.1: JN. PYNCHEON, 1392. Will of Jn. Pyncheon, Citizen and jeweller of London, dated, Vigil of St. Matthew [Sept. 20], 1392. [John Pyncheon's will is in French, with an English insertion, perhaps in order that his charitable gifts might thus be more plain.  He gives money to the Poor, according to their condition; clothes to the Lame and Blind; a weekly allowance to the Prisoners in Newgate, and the Lepers, for 1 year; and a small sum to poor men of Religion.] 1 Commissary Court off London, Courtney. (xiij. 264. 194 lf. 1. 19) Gives his lands in the county of Essex to be sold, and the money dispozed of as follows: "Ieo volle que la moneye soit despendu, cestassauoir, to þe pore Men þat han ben Men be-fore of god conuersacion, som man .xx.s, ant som ij Mar&ctee;, and som xl. s., aftyr þat here stat hat ben be-fore, and þat þey be of þe same Parche, and Of Petris and Cristoforys, or of oþere next þer by; & where me may wetyn eny powre lame, ore powre Blynde, in Ani plache in þe Towne, þat þey han Cloþys to hele hem fro colde, & Schetys to þam þat han nede.  And to þe presonis of newgate, a serteyn by þe weke duryng on &yogh;ere; & to þe Powre Mesellis a certeyn A weke duryng on &yogh;ere; & þat þe hows be ysol&dtail;, and þe Almes yi-do i&ntail; þe worst &yogh;ere.  And where men may a-spye eny powre man of religion, Monke, Chanon, or Frere, þat þay han of my god þe gode so in MS. , An&dtail; ben powre, eche Man .vj. s. viij. &dtail;. þat ben Prestys." (Proved, with Codicil annext, Oct. 9, 1392.)

0.1: [Of Hinton Marcel, Hampshire.  Gives her son Thomas, her best Bed and Seat, his father's ring, &c.;  Her daughter-in-law Joan, her second best Bed, a silver Basin and Chafer, her Books, Chapel Vestments and silver fittings, with a Chair and Chariot.  Her daughter Lady Alianore Clifton, a Bed, silver Basin, &c.;  Her sister, Lady Lucy Fitzherbert, Prioress of Shaftesbury, £40.  Bequests to her servants and poor tenants. Many gifts to Nuns, and Friars, and Recluses, for Masses and Prayers. Burial to be at the Priory of Christ-Church, Hampshire.] [Latin prologue as to the proof of the Will on Sept. 1, 1395, by Sir Thomas West and John Thurston, two of the Executors named in it.]

On thursday, that is to sey, the xv day of the monetℏ of July, In the yer of the incarnacioun of ou&rtail; lord ihesu crist, a thousand and thre hundred and foure score and fiftene, .I. Alice West, lady of Hyntōn Marcel, in hool estat of my body, and in good mynde beynge, make my testament in the mane&rtail; as hit folwetℏ here after.  In the begynnyn>ail;, I bequethe my soule to god almygℏty and to his moder seynt Marie, and to al the seyntis of heuene, and my body to be beryed in Criscℏercℏ in the Priorie of the Chanones in Hamptschire, by the Newe forest, where-as myne Auncestres liggetℏ. 1.1: [Codicil.  Revokes her gifts of goods to her Son and Daughter-in-law if they won't act as Executors As Sir Thos. West proved the Will (with Jn. Thurston), he and his Wife would keep their beds, books, &c ; and gives money to the other Executors who do act.]

.I. Alice West, lady of Hynto&nmacr; Marcel befornemed, hool of my body and in good mynde, beynge mor folly avised to dispose of this testament and my laste wil, .I. wol that, if it so be that Thomas my sone forseyd, and Iohane his wif, wolle nogℏt take the charge to be myne executors, and to parfourne the administracion of this testament, whicℏ is [my] laste wil, as it is wrete he&rtail;-before, thanne .I. wole that alle the godis whicℏ that .I. haue deuysed to the forseyd Thomas my sone and Iohane his wif in this testament, be solde by myn executours whicℏ wol take the charge herof, and trewely ydo to charitable werkes for my lordes soule, Si&rtail; Thomas West, and for myn, and for al cristene soules.  Also my wil is, that if eny of myne othe&rtail; executours forsaid, that is to saye, sir Ioℏn Colma&nmacr;, Thomas Remys, and Ioh&nmacr; Thursto&nmacr;, wol take the charge, and be myn executour by hem self, to parfourne this testament, if so be that non of myne othe&rtail; executours wol take the charge witℏ hem, thanne .I. wole, that after Thomas my sone forseyd, and Iohane his wif haue forsake to be myn executours, that he that taketℏ the charge to be myn executour, haue .xx.&lbar;i for his orwene for owene. trauayle; and if tweye of hem that ben myne executours forseyd wol take the charge to-gederes of executours to parforn trewely this testament, thanne .I. wol that after Thomas my sone and Iohane his wif haue forsake to be myne executours, that they tweye that taketℏ the charge to be myne trewe executours, have xx Mar&ctee; for he&rtail; trauaylle, that is [to] seye, eyther of hem x Mar&ctee;.  And if so be that si&rtail; Ioh&nmacr; Colman, Thomas Remys 
 and Ioℏn Thursto&nmacr;, myne executours forsey&dtail;, wolle take charge to-gederes to administre and to parfourne trewly this testament as hit is writen here before / thanne .I. wole that after Thomas my sone forsay&dtail; and Iohane his wif haue forsake to be myne executours, that the forsey&dtail; Sir Ioℏn Colma&nmacr;, Thomas Remys, and Ioℏn Thursto&nmacr;, haue .xx. &lbar;i for he&rtail; trauaille, that is to seye, euerycℏ of hem x Mar&ctee;. Also, for hit was for-yete byfore in this testament, .I. bequethe to the Reclus of Shirbour&nmacr;, whos Surname is Arthour, xl. s. for to do and to preye as othere Reclus forsey&dtail; Shulletℏ don and preye.  Accepta sunt hec, coram dicto Reuerendissimo presidente & domino Archiepiscopo, & per eum prout suprascribuntur & recitantur.  Anno, Indictione, pontificatu, Mense, die & loco, predictis.  Presentibus venerabilibis & discretis viris, Magistris Adam de Mottrun, Archidiacono Cantuarensi in decretis, & Waltero Gybbes in legibus licenciatis, testibus ad premissa vocatis specialiter & rogatis. See an Abstract of this Will in Nicolas's Testamenta Vetusta , 1826, i. 137; Collins's Peerage , v. 378; and an extract in Dugdale's Baronage , ii. 139.  It was printed in the Illustrated London News of (?).

JOHN GIRDELER, 1402. [Of Harefield (near Uxbridge, Middx.): to be buried at Westminster Abbey.  Bequests to St. Paul's, Westminster Abbey, the parish churches of Harefield (and its poor, priest, and clerk), Ikenham, Ruislip, and Helmdon, These places are in the hundred of Elthorne, Middx., and near Uxbridge, from which town, Harefield (Virgin Mary) is 4 1/4 miles N., Ickenham (St. Giles) is 2 3/4 miles N.E., and Ruislip (St. Martin) is 3 1/2 miles N.E.— Lewis, Topogr. Dict. , 1833 . Helmdon, Middx., is not in Lewis, but must be near the others. and to 120 poor bedrid folk of Westminster; and £2 to mend the road between Hillingdon and Acton.] (Brown 1400-1418.  2 Commissary Court of London, leaf 21 back.) In the name of god, Amen. þe xxv day of Iuyll i&ntail; þe reigne of Kyng Henry, iij &yogh;er .I. Iohn Girdeler of Harfel&dtail;, in god mynde and saf memorye, make my testement.  Ferst my soule to Almyghty 



 go&dtail;, my body for to rest in the Chirche of Synt pietres at Westmenstre, where as þe Abbot wol asyne.  And y bequethe to þe werk of Synt powles of londo&ntail; vj s. viij d.  Also y bequethe to þe Couent of Westmenstre x mar&ktee;.  Also y bequethe for vj torchis of wax for to serue atte awter of Synt pieter in þe worschipe of go&dtail; xl .s.  Also y bequethe to þe paricℏ chirche of Harfel&dtail; xx .s.  Also y bequethe to þe heye awter of þe forsey&dtail; chircℏ, ij torchis of wax. for to serue in the worschip of go&dtail; xiij s iiij d.  Also y bequethe atte day of my terment in Harfeld, to an .C. pouere men and wommen, for þe loue of go&dtail;, euerych I.&dtail;.  Also y &yogh;eue to þe paricℏ prest of Harfeld x .s. Also y wille þat William my&nmacr; so&ntail; haue þe maner of Chale, with alle þe purtenaunce beynge in fefyes handes, with  a-vowso&nmacr; of þe Chyrche in þe Ile of Wygℏt, to him & to hys heirs of ys body lawfully be-goto&nmacr;; and yf he deie wytℏ-owte heire lawfully of ys body begeto&nmacr;, þanne wille y þe forseyd maner with appurtenaunce, remayne to Henre ys broþer, and to þe heirs of ys body lawfully goto&nmacr;; and yf þe forsey&dtail; Henre deie with-owt issue leful of ys body goto&nmacr;, thanne wille y þat þe forseyd maner with appurtenauns, remayne to me and myne heirs.  Also y wille þat Henre my sone have .x. Marcis wortℏ londe &yogh;hely yearly. to hym and to ys heirs leful of ys body, of þe londes and þe rentes in þe Counte of deuo&ntail;-schire, beynge in fefees handes, with a-vowsoune of þe chirche of Mounkcocamto&nmacr;; an&dtail; for defawt of issue comynge of þe forseyd henre, y wille þat yt remayne to william ys broþer, and to ys heirs of ys body.  And for defawte of issue of þe forsey&dtail; William, y wille þat þe remaynde&rtail; be to my ryte heirs.  I pray yow also þat ben my Feffees, þat &yogh;e make estate vn-to my forseyd chyldre, lucie, henre, and william, lyke as my wylle ys be-fore conteynyd.  Also y wille þat Thomas Rawfe, my seruaund, haue .ij.  Marces &yogh;hely yearly. durynge ys lyfe, takynge yt of þe londes and rentes in deue&ntail;-schyre beynge in fefees handes, takynge a distresse in defawte of payment.  Also my wille ys, þat yf my wyfe or my chyldre asku&nmacr; here resnable part of my godes aftur cours of lawe, þan wille y þat þey be excludyd of alle þe avauntage of þe ordinauns of my wylle above y-seyd.  Also my wille ys, þat þe siluer þat schal be reseyvyd for þe londes & tenementes þat y haue be-fore asyngnyd for þe avaunscement of lucie my dowter, þat hyt a-byde in þe handes of my&ntail; executours to fulfyl my wille.  Also y wille, tochaunde þe londes þe weche y haue asynyd to william my sone, þat lucie my wyf have gouernauns þer-of, and þe profete, vn-to þe forseyd william be of age .xviij. &yogh;here.  And also of þe londes þat ben assyngnyd to henre, þat my wyfe have þe governauns and þe profyte of, vn-to þe forseyd henre be of age .xviij. &yogh;here.  Also y wylle þat þe .C. &lbar;i.  wyche y have assyngnyd for ysabe&llbar; my dowter, to hire a-vaunsement, and it falle þat sche deie or scheo be a-vauncyd, þan wille y þat þe forseyd .C. &lbar;i. be don for my sowle.  þe residue of alle my godes, my dettes furst payd, and my wille holly fulfyllid as ys by-fore wreto&ntail;, y wylle þat yt remayne to þe 



 forseyd lucie my wyfe.  and y pray alle &yogh;ow þat bene enfeffee&dtail; in my londes forseyd by me, þat &yogh;e fulfylle my forseyd wylle os &yogh;e wylle answere a-fore god.  Ad execucionem vero huius testamenti mei faciendam, ordino et constituo executores meos, laurencium dru, willelmum Stookes, Robertum Clerke, Rectorem ecclesie de Bradfel&dtail;, et Iohannem Iacob.  Datum die et Anno supradictis. probatum fuit hoc precedens testamentum coram Magistro Iohanne perche, Commissario &c primo die Mensis Octobris, Anno domini M o CCC. xj. et quibuscunque, probacione &c, per dominum Robertum Sarum Episcopum cassata &c, et commissa est administracio omnium bonorum dicti defuncti, quibusdam Roberto Clerk, Rectori ecclesie parrochiane de Bradfel&dtail;, Sarum diocese, & Iohanni Iacob, Executoribus &c.; laurencio dru, Executori eciam in ipso testamento nominato, coram dicto Commissario personaliter comparenti, onus administracionis &c expresse recusavit &c Reseruata potestate cuidam willelmo Stokes &c Et subsequenter, viz. x die Mensis decembris Ao domini predicto, prefatus Commissarius acquietavit prefatos Robertum Clerk & Iohannem Iacob, &c.
text.8:
RICHARD YONGE, BREWER, OF LONDON, 1413. [To be buried at St. Dunstan's in the West.  Gifts to that Church, and its Priests.  20s. to Mother.  Apprentice to be let off 2 years of his term, and have a grain vessel (?), &c.;  Son William to have pots, a pan, and a bed.  Residue to Wife and Son.] (Brown 1400-1418.  2 Commissary Court of London, leaf 263.) In the name of god, Amen.  Millesimo CCCC xiij, I, Richar&dtail; &yogh;onge, Brewer of Londo&ntail;, be-set my testament in thys maner: fyrst, I be-quethe my Soule to God al-my&yogh;ty, an tho tho is to ; an is and . our lady seynt Mary, an to al the fayr company of heuene; an my body tho be byret in the chirche &yogh;er&dtail; of Seynt Donstones in the West.  al-so y be-quethe to the hye Auter of the same churche, for oblacions for-etyn for-etyn is forgotten . , xij &dtail;. al-so y be-quethe to the sayd churche warkis, vj s. viij &dtail;.  al-so y 


 be-quethe to the prestes an the Clerkys that mynystre in the for-sayd churche, by euen porcyo&ntail; a-mong hem, iij s. iiij &dtail;.  al-so, yf ther may be spared so moche of my gode after my dedtis an rement of my testament be fulfyllyt, y wyl that my moder haue xx s .  Al-so [y] wyl that Io&ntail;, my prentys, haue a reles of to &yogh;er of hys hol termys, of thys condicyo&ntail;, that he be gode an trewe to my wyf.  al-so y be-quethe to the for-sede Io&ntail;, I graners, an a flot, an a planer.  al-so y be-quethe tho William my sone, a new bras pot, an a panne, an a bedde, an a potel pot of peuwter.  the residue of my gode, y be-quethe tho Amys my wyf, an my so&ntail;, to kepe hem boþ wyt.  al-so y make [lf. 263 back] Richar&dtail; Roos, Glouer, & Jo&nmacr; ma&ntail;, Corwaner, myn executou[r]s; & ayder of hem to haue for ther trayuay&llbar;, a gode bow. Probatum est hoc testamentum coram nobis.  Test&mtail; &c ije kl&ntail; Octobris, Anno supra dicto.  Et commissa est administracio omnium bonorum &c Executoribus supra dictis.

0.1: [One-third of sale-money of some land, to make the steeple of Marcle Church, one-third to poor Prisoners (debtors), 1/6th to neighbouring Poor, 1/6th for the Marriage of young Women.  1000 Masses to be said.  Restitution to be made for wrong-doing.  Wife to have household goods, cloven-footed beasts, and corn.  Burial to be without useless pomp. Legacies to Children, &c.;  Both Testament and Will have been printed in some book on the Walwayn family, Appx. p. 63-4.] Book 'March' (Prerog. Court), leaf 253.

Hereford, 5 miles S.W. by W. from Ledbury, in the archdeaconry and diocese of Hereford.—Lewis. retro patrem & matrem meos.  Item lego ecclesie Cathedrali 

 Herefordensi .C. s'.  Item volo quod Capellanus Canterie, per feoffatos meos fundate, statim celebret cotidie in ecclesia predicta pro anima mea & animabus patris [&] matris meorum, & animabus Antecessorum meorum. N. W. by N. from Newent; Dymock , 3 3/4 m. N.N.W. from Newent; Ledbury ; and Aylton , 4 1/4 m. W. from Newent; and one Putley , W. of Aylton, and 5 3/4 m. W. from Ledbury.  Another Putley is a township in the parish of Woolhope , co. Hereford, which is probably Wolfhope of our text, 7 3/4 m. W. by S. from Ledbury. How-Caple is in Herefordshire, 6 m. N.N.E. from Ross. Sollers Hope is west of Much Marcle, 7 1/2 m. N. by E. from Ross, and a little farther S.W. of Ledbury. ; And þat other half be &yogh;eifi to the maryage of yonge pore wommen yn the same paryssℏes by the disposicion of myn executours / and I wolle that ther be .x. M1. masses Isayde for me of gode prestes witℏ a&llbar; hast, and my dette payed, and restitucion made ther eny wronge may be Ifounde be donn, (as I trust to god but litu&llbar;,) by myn executours. And I wo&llbar; that Isabe&llbar; my wyfe haue a&llbar; the necessaries, clothes, braas, and other instrumentes of a&llbar; myn houshol&dtail;, And a&llbar; cloue-fote bestes that I haue, And a&llbar; my corne growyng and yn bernes atte Mercle and atte Massyngto&ntail;, oute take xl. quarters of wete reserued to fullfe&llbar; witℏ my wille, And an .C. mark of money.  And I wo&llbar; that MS. that that. my enterement be holde witℏ oute pompe, whyche may not profyt myn soule.  And I wo&llbar; that Richard my so&ntail; haue tweyne my best hors, And .xl. pounde.  Also I. wolle that Cristian my doughter haue to here mariage an .C. &lbar;i of the profites of longefor&dtail;; Maclun and William, euerychon of hem .xx mark.  Item lego priori Magne Maluerne .xl. &lbar;i.  Item lego Willelmo Walwayn, fratri meo 


 .xx &lbar;i. 1.0: [ Will of the Realty in Feoffees' hands. ]
1.1: [Wife to have for life, lands in Marcle, Ledbury and Eastnor.  On her death, Marcle lands to son Richard in tail, with remainder to nephew Thomas, and then nephew William, both in tail.  Ledbury and Eastnor lands to son Maclun in tail, with remainder to son William in tail, remainder to testator in tail.  Son Richard and his wife Clemence, to have other lands, in tail, with remainder to nephew Thomas in tail, &c.;  Other land, to found a perpetual chantry.  Thatley and Farley, to son Maclun in tail, with remainder to son William in tail, &c.;  Butterley and the Fen to son William in tail, with remainder to son Maclun in tail, &c.;  Longford to be held for 20 years by the Feoffees, and its profits (with sale-monies of Dean and Chalford) paid to testator's Executors to fulfil his Testament with. After the 20 years, Longford to go to Wife for life, with remainder to son William in tail, then to son Maclun in tail.  Aylton to son Richard.]

2.1: Memorandum, quod Thomas Walway&ntail;. Armiger, de Comitatu Herefor&dtail;, compos mentis, decimo nono die mensis maij, Anno domini Millesimo .CCCC. quintodecimo, recitans se nuper fecisse et condidisse suum testamentum super disposicione bonorum suorum, ad idem testamentum, per viam Codicilli, superaddebat & voluit quod [&c.; appoints his son Richard one of his executors, &c.] .
2.2: (Testament, Will & Codicil, proved by Isabella the widow, & Richard the son, on May 20, 1416; "and afterwards on 21 May a Commission was directed to the Prior of Great Malvern to make a Grant to the other Executors.— (Folio 32 Marche, C. P. C.) ."

text.10:
THOMAS BROKE, LANDOWNER, OF HOLDITCH, THORNCOMBE, DEVONSHIRE, 1417. [To be buried in Thorncombe Church, under a plain flat stone; not in a coffin, but only a cloth; and no feast to be held.  But 300 Poor to be fed, and have 3d. each, and 300 Children 1d.  Poor tenants to have £20 among em; the poorest tenant £100; and £10 and more to go as restitution for wrong-doing.  £100 to poor Blind and Lame.  Residue to Wife.] (March, leaf 316, back, Prerog. Court.) In the name of the Lorde of a&llbar; Lordes, the a&llbar;my&yogh;ty ymmortal Trinite, I, wrichy&dtail; Synne&rtail;, Thomas Broke, in gode Mynde, and out of Sekenesse, make my testamen&ttee;, &YOGH;yf it be the wi&llbar; of god, in this mane&rtail;, prayng him, of his hye yndelesse mercy, fouchesafe to receyue my wreche&dtail; vnclene soule in-to his mercy, and kepe hyt fram dampnacion, for the meke passyoun and detℏ that his debonure sonne, oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Cris&ttee;, Soffre&dtail; o&ntail; the Crosse for Cherite & pety of mankyn&dtail;.  And my wy&llbar; is, that my body be Berye&dtail; in the Chircℏℏey of the Parysℏcℏurcℏ of Thornecombe Thorncombe (St.  Mary), a parish (formerly a market-town) forming a detacht portion of the hundred of Axminster, co. Devon, 6 1/2 m. S. W. by W. from Axminster.  The owner of the old Cistercian Abbey at Ford in this parish, 'holds a court at Holditch' (see page 27).—Lewis. , as men gotℏ oue&rtail; 


 in-to þ is printed for y . þe churcℏ at þe Soutℏ Syde, ry&yogh;te as they mowe stappe on me / and a fla&ttee; playne stone, saue my name ygraued þa&rtail;-In, that men mowe the rathe&rtail; haue mynde on me, and pray for me.  And nethe&rtail; wheche ? hutch, chest, coffin. , ne leede, to be leyde in / bote a grete Clothe to hely my foule Caryin; and of Torches, bote .iij., and .iij. taprys; Ande no fes&ttee; noþer termen&ttee; yhol&dtail;, bot .iij., Masses atte my buryyn>ail;, saue CCC poure men schullen haue mete & drynke ynowe, and euery man and woman of ham .iij. &dtail;, & euery chyl&dtail; of .CCC. Childerne .I. [&dtail;], yf þer be so many Childerne / and .xiij. poure men clothe&dtail; in Russett ylyne&dtail; witt white, and euery of ham to haue .viij &dtail; / and I bequethe to my poure tenauntes of Holdycℏ, Hotham, Cherd There is a Chard in Somerset, 13 m. S.E. by S. from Taunton, and 12 E. from Honiton in Devon.—Lewis. , Cotteleygℏ Cotleigh , a parish in the hundred of Colyton, co. Devon, 3 m. E.N.E. from Honiton.—Lewis. , & Wycrofte Cp. Henry de Wicroft.—Prince's Worthies of Devon , 1810, p. 495. , that hauetℏ y&yogh;eue to me Capouns & bederpes Bedrepes .  Days of work performed in harvest time by the customary tenants, at the bidding of their lords. See Cullum's Hawsted , 1784, p. 189. Hall.'s Gloss.  The word is in Thorpe's Ancient Laws , i. 436, l. 4, and the new Bosworth's A.-Sax. Dict.  Prof. Skeat says it "is from A.Sax. beód-an , to bid, summon, and A.S. ríp , later M.E. rêp , a reaping (Stratmann gives rêp ). Cf. bidale . The sense is 'reaping done by summoned men.'" and Plouwys, &yogh;ou&yogh;e though. þey be nou&yogh;te my tenauntes, I wi&llbar; þat myn executours do he&rtail; gre by god discrecion atte þe value of xx &lbar;i amonge hame / and if any oþer man or woman be, that Cane Pleyne hym þat icℏ ℏaue oppresse&dtail; hy&mtail;, or do wrange to him, oþer yete with my bestys his Corne oþer his grase, and nou&yogh;te amendit ? MS. amende. hit to hy&mtail;; to amende sucℏ trespasses, I bequethe x. &lbar;i.: and I bequethe to a&llbar; my pourest tenauntes, where þat þey be, excepte ham þat I haue ynemne&dtail; in þis bok to-for, C. &lbar;i in mony / and I bequethe to Poure men blynd and lame .C. &lbar;i, and to sum trew man, by good discrecyo&ntail; to do party cause to be parted, divided. the mony forsey&dtail; / and namelycℏ iff ycℏ ℏaue do wronge to eny of my tenauntes or mys tak hir goo&dtail;, I wi&llbar; þat it be restore&dtail; to ham, whethe&rtail; it be Man or woman, be avysemen&ttee; of my&ntail; Executours, as þey wi&llbar; aunswere to-for go&dtail; at þe dome / and þe resyduwe of a&llbar; my goodys and Cate&llbar;, in this my testamen&ttee; nou&yogh;te  bequethede, ycℏ &yogh;eue Holelycℏ, and bequethe, to Iohane my wyfe, reseruynge alweys to me volle powe&rtail; to chaunge þis testament, oþer to mak hit more, oþer to amenusy hit, oþer to vndo hit a&llbar;, as ofte as me Lustetℏ, or whanne þat me lyketℏ, duryng my Lyfe.  and to do goo&dtail; and trewe execucion of þis my testament, ycℏ ordeyne and ma&ktee; myne Executours, Iohane my wyfe, William Brerdo&ntail;, sir Ioℏ&ntail; Dey, parsone of Bageworthe There's a Badgworth in Somerset, 2 1/2 m. S.W. by W. from Axbridge. , Raufe Perceuale, sir Edwar&dtail; Osbourne, vicary of Thornecombe.  This testament is my volle & hole wille þe day of þe date of þis my testament, the date in my Manou&rtail; of Holdecℏ, on Setrysday in þe vygyle of þe Holy Trynyte, the &yogh;ere of grace & of þe incarnacyoun of oure Lorde Ihesu Criste, M 1 , CCCC. mo xv o .  Thys twey Lynis I wrete almeste with my&ntail; owne Hon&dtail;. Probatum fuit hoc testamentum coram Magistro Iohanne Estcourt &c.;  vo. die Februarij, anno domini Millesimo CCCC .xvij o &&ctee;, & commissa administracio bonorum domino Edwar&dtail; Osbourne, vicario ecclesie parochiane de Thornecombe &&ctee;.  Reseruata potestate &c.; & habent diem ad exhibendum Inuentarium primo die iuridico post sanctum Pasche proximum in futuro &&ctee;, & subsequenter acquietancia fuit dicto executori &&ctee;.
text.11:
JOHN SOLAS, OF SOUTHWARK, SURREY, 1418. [To be buried in St. George's, Southwark.  Gifts to that Church, its Priests and Clerk.  Gifts of gowns and money to Servants and others, and of half a year's rent to E. Veel.  Residue to Wife.] (March, quire 42, lf. 337.) In the name o&ftee; the fader and the sone and the holy-gost, atte hye reuerens of oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Criste, an&dtail; of ys blessed moder seynte Marie, and of seynt Iohan the Ewangelis&ttee; and al other holy seyntes of heuene, I, Ion Solas of Southwer&ktee;, in good mynde and goo&dtail; deliberacio&ntail;, my testament I make yn thys forme: atte begynnyn>ail; I be-quethe my soule to our lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist and to oure lady seynte 
 Marie, and to alle aleves hallows, saints. of heuene / And my body to be beret in the northpart o&ftee; the Churche of seynt Gorge of Soutwerke / Also I be-quethe to that same Churchewer&ktee; C s'.  Al-so I be-quethe to the hye auter I Mar&ctee; / Also I be-quethe to euery preste that ther syngytℏ the day of my berynge / iiij &dtail; / Also I be-quethe the Cler&ktee; o&ftee; the same Churche xl. &dtail;.  Al-so I be-quethe to Io&nmacr; Euenwode iiij nobls, and a goune newe of bla&ktee;.  al-so I be-quethe to Thomas Elyot xx s' [&] a goune o&ftee; blak.  Al-so I. be-quethe to Ion Costert my seruaunt, x s' and a goune .. Also I be-quethe to Richar&dtail; my seruaunt I. noble, and a goune and a doblet.  Al-so y be-quethe to Ione ? MS. Ioern. Batesey, xl &dtail; and a goune / Al-so y wole that my wyfe and al my chyldre&ntail; be atte my berynge, yn case they leue.  Also I for-&yogh;eue Edeyn Veel / V Mar&ctee; / of here rente for an alfyere, yn case I deye. Al-so I be-quethe to Ion Bryxhy&llbar; a goune.  al-so I be-quethe to Thomas Wade a goune.  Al-so I be-quethe to William Mymmes a goune, and to Anneys ys wyfe a goune.  Also 'Also' is repeated in the MS. I be-quethe to Ion Archer a goune.  Also I be-quethe to Adam Rigge a goune / The remenaunt o&ftee; my godys that be not be-quethe ne &yogh;euen, I be-quethe to Ione my wyfe, for to do and ordeyne as sche thyngytℏ best, and as sche wole answere atte hey day of Iugement / To thys testament to ordeyne and parforme, I make myn executours, my wyfe a-boue seyd, Robert Bromesbury and William Horto&ntail;.  In the wytnesse of the wyche thynge, I haue set to my sele.  I-&yogh;eue&nmacr; atte South-wer&ktee; in the parsche of seynt Gorges, the xij day of Iuly, the &yogh;ere of ou&rtail; lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist M 1 CCCC xviij.  Probatum fuit testamentum coram Magistro Iohanne Estcourt, Comissario &&ctee;, vicesimo secundo die Mensis Iulij, anno domini M o CCCC mo xviij mo .  Et comissa fuit administracio Iohanne, Vxori & Executrici dicti defuncti, &&ctee;. Reseruata potestate &&ctee;.
text.12:
JOHN CHELMYSWYK, ESQ., SHROPSHIRE, 1418. [Gives £5 to Quatford church for his soul's sake.  40s. each to the Friars of Bridgnorth, Woodhouse, Shrewsbury, Ludlow, London; and to the Prisoners in Ludgate, Newgate, and the Marshalsea; and 20s. each to the 6 London Hospitals; to sing 30 Masses, and pray for his soul, his late wife's, his grandmother's, &c.;  £70 for 2 priests to sing 7 years for his soul, at Bridgnorth, and £2 for their vestments, and £7 to keep his Year's Mind there for 7 years; and at each Mind 20s. to be given to the Bridgnorth poor.  Jonet, his 2nd wife, to have (for her dowry, &c.;) £40 and his household goods, save gold and silver, &c.;  6 silver sawcers to be made into 2 Chalices for the 7-year priests.  Wife to have his Manor of Staverton for life (with remainder to his heirs in tail), and let Emot Roe, her mother, have Aspley, for which he's given his Bond for £400 to John Roe.  If testator dies childless, Staverton to be sold, and the produce go in Charity and Masses.  If his wife Jonet turns her mother out of Aspley, she's to be turnd out of Staverton, which is to go to his heirs in tail, or be sold as aforesaid.  Manors of Hay and Tasley to be sold and applied to Charity and Masses.  If wife Jonet keeps sole for a year, her state's to be kept up free.  Gold chain, &c.; to Wife.  Silver dishes, money, furrd gowns, &c.; to Executors.  Residue to be applied in Charity and Masses £5 to Tasley Church; and bedding, hangings, &c.; to the Parson of Tasley and R. Crowder.] (March, lf. 335 bk., P. C.) Testamentum Johannis Chelmiswyk. The thridde day of Apri&llbar; In þe &yogh;er off our lor&dtail; M 1 CCCC xxij .I. Peryne Clanbowe, beyng in good memory, thenkyng on my laste ende, hauyng gode in forsygℏt, I haue maad and ordene&dtail; this my present testament and my last wy&llbar;e in þe forme þat folowetℏ.  First I bequetℏ and commen&dtail; my saule to gode my make&rtail; and my sauyour, and to hys blyssyd mode&rtail; gloriouse Vyrgy&ntail;, And to a&llbar; saintes, and my body to be berye&dtail; at &yogh;asore, Yasor is in Herefordshire, 5 miles S. of Weobly. be my lor&dtail; my housbon&dtail;, If I. dye in Hertfordshire, That is, Herefordshire. and ellis where þat gode hatℏ ordeined for me, And as son as yt may be do&nmacr; godly after þat I hame dede, porelycℏ to be berye&dtail;, with-oute gret cost doon thervppo&nmacr;. Also I wi&llbar; And ordeine þat a&llbar; my dettes þat mowe be prowede be good conscience due, þat they be principaly payde in a&llbar; þe hast þat it may be. ? MS. mayle. Also I bequetℏ, to clotℏ wytℏ ijc. poormen, xx. &lbar;i. Also I bequetℏ to amende brygges and foule wayes x. &lbar;i.  Also I bequetℏ to sir Robert of Whitney, my brother, a flate basyn and an ewer, and vj disshes, vj saucers, and ij chargours of seluer.  Also I bequetℏ to þe same Robert a westment of rede clotℏ of gol&dtail; with my massbooke and Chalys: The wych vesse&llbar;, vestement, massbooke, and chalys aforsey&dtail;, to þe forsaide Rober&dtail; bequethe&nmacr;, I wole þat [he] haue hem 







 vpo&nmacr; this condicion, þat he be good fren&dtail; to my executours, and þat he lete hem note off ministracion off myn other goode on the Manere of Pychardisoke&llbar; ne elles where.  Also I bequetℏ to myn Aunte, prioresse of Lynebroke, xl s'.  Also I bequeth to myn Awnte Corbet, xl s'.  Also I bequetℏ to sir Ion Skydmore, Either Sir John Scudamore of Kentchurch, Herefordshire (who married the daughter of Owen Glendowr), living temp . H. IV., or his son and namesake.— H. Round. my newewe, a girde&llbar; of peerles.  Also I bequetℏ to Iane myn nece, to her mariage, or when sche is of age, xx &lbar;i.  Also I bequetℏ to Peryne her suster, my god doutghter in þe same forme, x &lbar;i; and if it so be þat þe forsai&dtail; Iane and Peryne dye be-for þat thay come to age, or ellys marie&dtail;, then I wi&llbar; þat þe mony of either of hem so deede, turn to þe vse of her susters ouerlyuyng in þe same fourme.  and if a&llbar; þe susters dye ar they come to age or be marye&dtail;, þat then þe mony tourn to þe vse of her bretheren ouerlyuyng.  And if a&llbar; þe bretheryn die with-In age of xvj. &yogh;eere, then þe mony be dispose&dtail; in Almasdeddes be my executours.  Also I be-queeth to Iankyn Myles my seruaunt, xx&lbar;i./, and myn eche daies gowne of marterount.  Also I bequetℏ to sir Iohan Coyle, I pare bedes of cora&llbar;.  Also I bequetℏ to Elizabetℏ Ioye .x. &lbar;i. and a booke of Englyssℏ, cleped "pore caytife," and I gown furre&dtail; with gret menyvere.  Also I bequetℏ to Ionet Okbourn .x mar&ctee; and my saute&rtail; helid with blake, and a gown furre&dtail; with Cristy gray.  Also I bequetℏ to Ioℏn Huchecoke, v mar&ctee;.  Also I bequetℏ to Ianky&nmacr; Tailour, v mar&ctee;. Also I bequetℏ to Dauid Morys, xl s'.  Also I bequetℏ to Ioℏn Hergest, xl s'.  Also I bequetℏ to Luysote xl s'.  Also I bequetℏ to the wyffe of Ianky&ntail; Miles a gown furred with Besshe.  Also I bequetℏ to Dauid Cradoke xiij s' iiij &dtail;.  Also I bequetℏ to Iames and to his wyfe x s'.  Also I bequetℏ to þe chircℏ of &yogh;asore, fore my lor&dtail; and his auncetres, to serue in þe chircℏ, a peire vestimentis of blake, wherof þe same Chircℏ hatℏ þe cope.  Also I bequetℏ to what thenge þat is most necessary in þe same Chircℏ, v. mar&ctee;.  Also I bequetℏ to Ionet Knolles a stondyng cuppe of siluer gilte couere&dtail;.  Also I bequetℏ to Thomas Knolles þe &yogh;ongge&rtail; a cuppe of siluer gilt couere&dtail;.  Also I bequetℏ to Ioℏn Thomas a cuppe of siluer play&nmacr;. with þe scripture of seynt Ion.  Also I bequetℏ to two prestes, honest men and goo&dtail; liues, and ellys not, to do diuine seruise for my lor&dtail; and me. for on &yogh;er anoon After my decees, resonable lyuelode after þe discrecioun of my&nmacr; executours. Also I bequetℏ to sir Reynol&dtail;, my prest, iiij. quayres of Doctours on Mathewe.  The Residue for sotℏ of a&llbar; my goodes in this my testament not bequethen, I &yogh;eue and bequethe to myn executours, be her discrecion to be disposyde, that oon halfe to my pore tenauntz, and þat other halfe to god men faithfu&llbar; and nedy þat ben in disese. And to þe execucion of this my testament and my last wi&llbar; to be fulfille&dtail;, I ordeyn my trusty frendes, Ianky&ntail; Miles, Thomas Knolles aforsai&dtail;, Elizabetℏ Ioy, Ionet Okborne, and Ioℏn Tailour, myne executours be thees presentes, that they wi&llbar; do her besynesse to fulfy&llbar; goddes wi&llbar; and myne, as they wo&llbar; aunsuer afor gode. also I bequetℏ to icℏ of my&ntail; executours takyng charge of ministracion of this my testament, v. mar&ctee;, and rewar&dtail; for her costages whan they labour specially for my maters.  Into wy&ttee;nessyng of whicℏ thyng, to this my present testament I haue put to my see&llbar;: &yogh;eue&nmacr; at Londo&ntail;, day, monetℏ, and &yogh;er, aforsay&dtail;. Probatum fuit presens testamentum coram Magistro Iohanne Estcourt & &ctee;, xviij o die Mensis Nouembris, Anno domini Millesimo xxij do &&ctee;, et commissa fuit administracio Iohanni Miles, Elizabethe Ioy, Iohanne Okbourne et Iohanne Tailour, executoribus &&ctee; Reseruata potestate & &ctee;, et habent ad exhibendum Inuentarium: ac secundo die Mensis Decembris Anno domini supradicto, acquietati fuerunt executores supradicti, & soluerunt pro fine iiij or nobilia. The pore Caytife (p. 50, l. 18) is a collection of religious tracts against abuses in the Romish Church, known by this common title, and formerly attributed to Wycliffe, tho wrongly, by Bp. Bale and others.  On the authorship of it, see Shirley's Introduction to Fasciculi Zizaniorum , p. xiii, note 3.  MSS. of it are Harleian 2335, -6, -9, &c.; &c.; and part of it is in Douce 322, leaf 100.

SIR ROGER SALWAYN, KNIGHT, OF YORK, 1420. [To be buried in the Grey Friars at York, with a flat marble stone over him.  Gifts to the 4 Orders of Friars in York.  All houshold goods and £500 to Wife.  £400 for land for Son.  Marriage portions for Daughters. Debts to be paid out of rents.  Poor Tenants to be let off.  A pilgrim to be sent to Jerusalem, at not more than £100. Gifts of Money and Horses to Relativs and Friends.  Old Servants to be rewarded.  Gifts of Armour.  Money to Nun who nursd Testator in sickness.  40s. Annuity to a man.  Furd garments to be sold for Testator's soul.] (March, P. P. C., lf. 437 back.) Testamentum Rogeri Saluayn, militis. [ In margin .] In the name off gode, I, sir Roger Salwayn, Knygtℏ, þ is for 'y' all thru. þe xxvj. day off October in the yer off our lor&dtail; M 1 CCCC xx. makys my testament in this maner .ffirst, I wyte my soule to gode almythty, to our lady seynt Mary, and to a&llbar; þe seinttes of hewi&nmacr;, and my bones to ben beriede in þe grey frerres atte &yogh;orke.  Also I. wi&llbar;. that ther where my bones sha&llbar; be beryde, be a flate sto&nmacr; off marbi&llbar;, ewy&nmacr; with the grounde.  Also I wi&llbar; þat þe forsaid freres haue a&llbar; my gownes off clotℏ off gol&dtail; and off sylke, with-outyn þe ffurres.  Also I wi&llbar; þat þe same frers haue xl. &lbar;i. for to synge and pray for me.  Also I wi&llbar; þat ilkon off þe other thre ordirs in &yogh;orke haue x mar&ctee;.  Also I wi&llbar; þat my wyffe haue a&llbar; my housholde holy, with vel &lbar;i that is in hir handes.  Also I wi&llbar; þat ther be ordeine for byynge off londe for Ioℏn Salway&nmacr; my so&nmacr;, CCCC &lbar;i; Also for þe mariage off Aliso&nmacr; my doughtir, CCCC mar&ctee;; Also for þe mariage off Isabe&llbar; my doughtir, CCC mar&ctee;.  Also I wi&llbar; þat my fader dettis, and my moders, be paide off my goode&yogh; that is in the Coillors Collectors.  Fr. cueillir , to cull, collect. or in þe fermors handes off my rent; and if any tenaunt be so pouer that he may nougℏt, for pouertee, pay his ferme that is owing, I wi&llbar; þat ther be nougℏt reseyued off hym, but þat he may resonably pay, and þat þe 



 remenaunt be for-&yogh;effy&nmacr;.  Also I wi&llbar; þat som goode man be ordeine to goo for me to Iherusalem in pilgremage, and as far as is cost is lese than C &lbar;i in commyng and goyng, þat hit be &yogh;ewy&ntail; for my soule to poure men wher most ? most nede of. allmose is.  Also I wi&llbar; þat Richard Chace haue v mar&ctee; off monee, and a bay hors þat was Gerar&dtail; my so&nmacr;; William Lister xx&lbar;i.  Thomas Fairchil&dtail; xl mar&ctee;, Acris Mersk .xx. &lbar;i; liti&llbar; Petir, liar&dtail; grey. Manley and x. mar&ctee;, and þat Acris Mersk haue þe grey geldyng; Gerar&dtail; and Ioℏn my brethir, liar&dtail; grey. botiller, and a sorede sorrel, red roan? horse þat was bougℏt off Henude&nmacr;, and þat Edward my brethir chese.  Also I wu&llbar; þat Gerar&dtail; my brodir haue xl. &lbar;i, and Thomas my brothir a place in Duffelde, ? Duffield on the Derwent, N. of Derby.— Walker's Gazeteer, 1801 . termyn off his liue, þat I purchesede off Ioℏn Fulthorpe; and after the desese off hym, to turn agayn to þe regℏt haiers off me.  Also I wi&llbar; þat sir Robert Shottesbroke, ? MS. Shoccesbroke. knyngℏt, haue þe sorde hors; and liti&llbar; Hans þe hoby, a small horse: 'the hobbie of Ireland' is among Harrison's 'outlandish horses.'  Part II, p. 5 of my edn.  New Shakspere Soc. and xl .s'. above&nmacr; his hir.  Also I wi&llbar; that Frost Mores and liti&llbar; Roby&nmacr;, ilko&nmacr; off them, haue xl s'.  Also I wi&llbar; .þat Pomfrettℏ, ? MS. Pomsrecch. skynner, of &yogh;orke, be paie&dtail; of v. or vj. &lbar;i, whedir þat hit be, for furres þat my lady my moder knowes off.  Also I wi&llbar; þat William Tropme&llbar;, taillour, of Londo&ntail;, and Hunt, brouderere, be paied of their billes for makyng off a liuerey of my&nmacr;.  Also I wi&llbar; þat Henry Loun&dtail; haue a blake goun furre&dtail; v1 funes, ? with funes, trimd with 'foynes,' or martin skins.  See Fouinne in Cotgrave. and a habirgoun of Mylen, opyn be-for, þat Richard Ste&llbar; haues in hys kepyng.  Also I. wi&llbar; þat &yogh;iff any seruaunt of myn haue labor&dtail; for me in my countree sen my fader die&dtail;, þat they be resonably rewardid aftir the seruice þat they haue do&nmacr;.  Also &yogh;if any man can aske any dete off me, other be euidence, or þat they be credibi&llbar; persones, I wi&llbar; þat they be paie&dtail;.  Also I wi&llbar; that Ely&nmacr; Saluay&nmacr;, my brothir Gerar&dtail; doughtir, haue xl. mar&ctee;. for hir mariage.  Also I wi&llbar; þat Gerar&dtail; my brothir haue a newe fure of martirs, See p. 36, above. and I. habirgoun The Habergeon was a smaller and lighter coat of mail or plate than the Hauberk, and was sometimes worn under that: see Chaucer's Sir Thopas .  It had sleeves in Wace's time, as he tells us that Bp. Odo's haubergeon at the Battle of Hastings was loose in the body, and tight in the sleeves. 1876. Planché, Cycl. of Costume , i. 236. of millo&ntail;. 













 Also I wi&llbar; þat Ioℏan my brothir haue I habirgoun of Gessera&nmacr;. A light flexible piece of armour 'composed of small overlapping pieces of  steel, fastened by one edge upon canvas, which was covered with cloth, silk, or velvet, the gilt heads of the rivets that secured the plates forming an ornament on the outside.  It was used for cuisses, brassarts, and other portions of harness; but very generally in the 14th and 15th centuries [and no doubt in the Will abuv] for jackets.' 1876.  Planché, Cycl. of Costume , i. 313. (See the woodcuts of two Jazerant Jackets on p. 314.) Also I wi&llbar; þat þe Nonne þat kepid me in my seknes haue ij nobles, and þat ther be &yogh;if in-to the hous þat she wonnes in, .xx. s'. for to syng and pray for me.  Also I wi&llbar; þat Thomas Faarchil&dtail; haue as mycℏ monee as he may purches hym .xl s'. be &yogh;er.  Also I wi&llbar; þat a&llbar; þe ffurrurs þat I haue, be soul&dtail; and doon for my saule.  Also I wi&llbar; þat Chace haue a habirio&nmacr; of myne. executors o&ftee; my testament, I wi&llbar; and ordeine Piers de la Hay, Gerar&dtail; Saluay&ntail;, Robert Rodesto&ntail;, sir Nichol Dixson, Clerk, Robert Cawode, Robert Day, Richar&dtail; Chace, and Thomas Fairchil&dtail;, to whom I &yogh;iff and wit þe residue of a&llbar; þe good and cate&llbar; þat I haue, þat they ordeine and dispose hit in sicℏ wys as may be most meritory for my soule, as they wi&llbar; aunswere be-for gode on dredfull day of doom. And the surveiors of my testament, I wi&llbar; and ordeine William Kylwolmerssℏ, Clerke, and my wyfe; wyttnessyng William Philipe Chiualer, Richar&dtail; Wodevi&llbar;, William Lister, and other.  Also I wi&llbar; þat William Lister haue as mycℏ of monee as the sorde hors is wortℏ, þat Shottesbroke haues. Probatum fuit presens testamentum coram Magistro Iohanne Estcourt, commissario &ca, septimo die mensis Marcij, Anno domini Millesimo CCCC mo xxij do & Commissa fuit administracio omnium bonorum dicti defuncti, Ricardo Chace & Thome Faarchyl&dtail;, executoribus in dicto testamento nominatis; et habent ad exhibendum Inuentarium citra festum pentecosti proximum iam futurum. [This ends the English Wills in Register 'March.']

Ego, Rogerus Flore, miser et indignus, de Okeham, compos mentis, laudetur altissimus, xvo die Aprilis, Anno domini Millesimo ccccmo xxiiijto, condo testamentum meum in hunc modum. 0.3: "Et ad istam execucionem bene et fideliter faciendam, ordino et constituo Iohannem Clerk de Wyssenden, Radulphum Humberstone de leicestria, Ricardum Hawey, Magistrum cantarie de Manto&nmacr;, & Willelmum Baxtir, custodem Hospitalitatis de Okeham, Executores meos, ad disponendum & exequendum testamentum meum. & voluntatem meam predictas, cum superuisione Henrici Plesynto&nmacr; militis, prout velint coram summo Iudice respondere" ......

1.2:
[I. Testament of the Personalty.] In þe name of almyghty god, fader and so&nmacr; and holy gost, Amen. I, Roger Flore of Okeham Oakham , a parish and market-town, in the soke of Oakham, county of Rutland, of which it is the chief town, 95 miles N.N.W. from London.—Lewis. , declare my last wi&llbar; in þis bille, als 

 we&llbar; of my testament as of my lan&dtail; þat stande&yogh; in feffe&yogh; The final '&yogh;' is generally a contraction for es, so that 'feffe&yogh;' may be 'feffees'; but as both 'brerdes' and 'brerde&yogh;' are uzed for the same thing below, '&yogh;' had better be read 'z' here.  'feffes' is on p. 60, as well as 'feffe&yogh;.' handes. First I wille þat my testament be, witℏ the grace of god, fulfille&dtail;; and as touching my housholde, my wille is, þat Thomas my sone haue a&llbar; my seluere vesse&llbar; þat I haue atte London, þat is to sey, a basyn and an Ewe&rtail; of syluere, too gilt peces flat couered, too peces of siluere whit with. lowe feet, þe oone couere&dtail; witℏ gilt brerdes, and þre goblettes of syluere, oone couere&dtail;, and a pote&llbar; pot of syluere, and a syluere sale&rtail;, and a doseyn spones of too suites, and fou&rtail; chargeours, six disches, and six saucers of siluere merkid witℏ a sink foil vnder þe brerde&yogh;.  Also I wul he haue al myn other houshool&dtail; þat I haue atte Londe&nmacr;, except my bed of Tapistree, þe whicℏ I wu&llbar; my welbeloved wife Cecile haue; þe whicℏ houshol&dtail; is in myn In, in keping of my seruaunt Rolleston by bille endente&dtail;, of whicℏ þe oone bille is in my trussing cofe&rtail;.  I wol also my sayd sone Thomas haue my paled bed of wurste&dtail;, white and rede, witℏ þe costers þe whicℏ seruen for my chambre I lye Inne atte Okeham, and a rede bed of wurste&dtail; witℏ þe costers the whicℏ hengen in þe newe chambe&rtail; next my chambe&rtail;; and I wu&llbar; he haue to þe oone bed a peyre fustyans, and to þe oþer a peyre blankettis, and to ilk of þe too beddis too peyre schetys goode, and a matras and a canvas; and I wu&llbar; he haue oon fetherbed; and I wu&llbar; he haue too seruauntes beddys for þe too said chambers.  I wu&llbar; also he haue too fyne bordeclothes, þe one of werk, þe oþer playn, witℏ goode sanapes hand-napkins. and wasshyngtowels, boþe for befo&rtail; mete and afte&rtail;.  Also I wu&llbar; he haue my mase&rtail; of a vine rote, the whicℏ was my faders, and þe peces of syluere made in þe boþum like perles, and too pottis of bras, and too pannes, and too spytes, and a peyre rakkes of yryne, and to brandernes, and to doseyn of pewter vesse&llbar;, and too cors bordcloþes, and too peire cors sanapes, and þre candelstykes of lato&nmacr;.  Also I wu&llbar; he haue my cartes and my plowes, and a&llbar; my hors þat longen to hem, whitℏ a&llbar; he&rtail; gere. also I wu&llbar; he haue my grete mase&rtail; þe whicℏ I calle &yogh;ele ? MS. &yogh;ole. , for þe terme of his life, and so from hei&rtail; to hey&rtail; lome: and no man merueil 









 þogℏ I do we&llbar; to him, for when almyghty god list to take me oute of þis wreched world to his mercy, þan sha&llbar; he be left faderles and moderles, grauntfaderles and grauntmoderles.  And yf hit so befe&llbar; þat he died, leuyn>ail; me, þan wu&llbar; I þat myn eldest sone þat ouereleuetℏ me haue hit hit = hit þat. what, the property which. I haue be-qweythen my say&dtail; sone Thomas. More ouere I wu&llbar; þat Robert my so&nmacr; haue my flat couere&dtail; pece whitℏ a sqware pome&llbar;, and an oþer flat pece of þe suit þat were my faders, (of whos soule god haue mercye,) and six spones of syluere; and Iames my so&nmacr; þe keuered pece þe whicℏ þe perso&nmacr; of Bereughby gaf me, and six spones of syluere; and Roger my so&nmacr; þe keuered pece of syluer þe whicℏ was mayster Robertis Stoneham, and is pounces whitℏ a crane, and six seluere spones ouer þe other keuere&dtail; pece, þe whicℏ my lor&dtail; Le Ware gaf him whan he was cristne&dtail;; and Ioh&ntail; my so&nmacr; a keuere&dtail; pece and six spones of silue&rtail;; and I wul þat my sai&dtail; so&nmacr; Robert haue my best gilt pece keuere&dtail;, and Roger my sai&dtail; sone my gilt keuere&dtail; goblet þat was Camews.  Also I wu&llbar; þat Anneys my doughter haue þe standing pece þat was my faders, keuere&dtail;, and my gilt pece þat Steneby gaf me, and a quart pot of silue&rtail;, and six spones of silue&rtail;, and a basyn and an Ewe&rtail; of silue&rtail;; and my doughte&rtail; Ioh&ntail; a keuere&dtail; pece of silue&rtail;, þe which þe provest of Coderstoke gaf me, and six siluer spones; and I wul þat ilk of my said childre haue a bed, þat is to say, couerlide, tapite, blankettis, too peyre schetes, matras, and canvas.  And þan wul I þat my welbeloue&dtail; wyfe Cecile haue alle þe remenaunt of my syluere vesse&llbar;, pottes, peces, and spones, basyn and Ewe&rtail; of siluere, powderbox and salers of siluere, beddyn>ail;, napery and pewter vesse&llbar;, brasse spytes, rakkes and brandernes of erne; and a&llbar; myn other howshol&dtail;, saf suche as longetℏ to þe gamerye, I wul abyde to myn hey&rtail;.  And I wul þat non of my cor&nmacr;, nor malt, ne quyk catel, be taken for houshol&dtail;, but I wul it helpe to fulfulle my testament, saf þat I wul þat my wyf haf of my corn and malt als myche as hire nedetℏ, til newe come, by delyueraunce of myn Executours, if she wul holde houshol&dtail;.  And I wul my wyf haf half my mylche kye, and myn hey&rtail; þe othe&rtail; half. And after my principal is taken, I wul my wyf haf my best ambele&rtail;, and my sone, sir Herre Plesyngto&nmacr;, wylk him likeþ best, afte&rtail; preying 

 hym to be gode maystre to my children; and þen wul I þat my so&nmacr; Thomas haf þe best next; and þe remenaunt of my rode horses I wul be departy&dtail; betwene my wyfe and my so&nmacr; Thomas; but I wul my wyf chese first.  Also I wul þat my gownes for my body, þe whicℏ ben ffurre&dtail; whitℏ pelure, be dalt amongis my childre, to ilke after here degre and age, so þat Thomas and Anneys haue fou&rtail; of þe best. And I wul þat þe remenaunt of my cloþes for my body be dalt amonges my seruauntes,—of þe whicℏ I wul that Thomas Campio&nmacr; be þought on—to ilke after þeyr degrees.  And .I. wul þat Robert my so&nmacr; haue oon of my swerdes, and one of my basilardes harneyse&dtail; witℏ siluere, and one of my siluere girdeles.  And I wul þat Thomas my sone haue myn oþer siluere girde&llbar;, and myn oþer wepen and armeru&rtail;.  Also .I. wul þat Thomas my sone haue my termes þat I haf of Westminster in þe personage of Okeham.  Also I wi&llbar; þat þe money þe whicℏ I haue be-qweþen to my childre to ? read 'be.' putte in sure keping be myn Executours, so þat þey mowe haue þat is be-qweþen hem when þei come to &yogh;eres of discrecion, if þey lif so longe; and elle þat it mowe be disposyd by myn Executours as I haue ordeyned by my testament, requirynge my sei&dtail; Executours, as þey wul onswere to god, þat þey (for no fauour) put hit but as þey suppose and truste be he&rtail; consciens it shal be sure. And I wil þe Maiste&rtail; of Manto&nmacr; haf my pai&rtail; of bedys þat I vse my self, witℏ þe x aues of siluere, and a pater noster ouer-gilt, preying him to haue mynde of me sumtime whan he seitℏ oure lady sawter on hem.  Also I wil þat Ioh&nmacr; B&rtail;igg and William Lewes haf, ilke of hem, xl. s'. for here oold seruice; and Robert Martfel&dtail; .xiij. s', iiij &dtail;; and koc kook Cock, the cook (?). a noble, and Toume [so] Campio&nmacr; a noble.  and if þe voute Voulte : f. a vault or arch; also, a vaulted or embowed roofe. 1611.—Cotgrave. of Okeham stepil be not made in my lif, þe whicℏ I haf made couenaunt of witℏ Thomas Nunto&nmacr;, Maso&nmacr;, to gif him .v. mark for þe werkmansshipe, 






 (of þe whicℏ I haue paied him a noble on ernest,) I wol þe same couenaunt be fulfilli&dtail; of my good after my decesse as sone as myn necbours wul ordeyn for þe stuffe þat sha&llbar; go þer-to, of þe whicℏ stuffe Richar&dtail; Oxenden haiþ paie&dtail; to Fairchil&dtail;, quarriour, xiij s' and iiij &dtail; for freestone.  More-ouer I wu&llbar; þat Thomas my so&nmacr; haue my portoos, charging him, on my blessing, that he kepe hit, terme of his lif, so that god wu&llbar; her-afte&rtail; sende him deuocio&nmacr; to sey his seruice þer-o&ntail;, as I haue done, þat þenne he may haue sucℏ a good honest boke of his owne; and if god ewre ? ure , destine. And I pray to þe blessed Trinite that of his endles mercye and goodnesse he sende my children grace to be gode men and wommen, and to &yogh;elde him gode soules, þorougℏ þe helpe and praier of oure lady seint Marye, and of a&llbar; þe seyntes of heune. Roger Flore, ouerseying my testament and wille, haue conceyue&dtail; þat I haue not ordeyned what Iames my so&nmacr; shulde haue during his moder lyf, soole, whithouten husbonde, þerfore my wille is, þat my ioint feffe&yogh; of my purchace of Leesthorpe Leesthorpe , in the hund. of Gartree, though locally situate in the hund. of Guthlaxton, Co. of Leicester; in the Parish of Pickwell ... It is 4 m. S.E. by S. from Melton Mowbray.— Carlisle in Leicestreshire, graunte by he&rtail; dede, to Iames my sai&dtail; sone, an annuite of .C s' of my sai&dtail; purchas of Leesthorpe, to haue hit for terme of his moder lif Cecile, if she lyue sool, so þat, after he&rtail; decesse, or if she take hi&rtail; an husbon&dtail;, he mowe haue þe remaindre of Braceby, like as I haue ordeine&dtail; for him in my wi&llbar;, so þat whanne þe remaindre falleþ to him, þat þanne þe saide annuite of an C s' sese.  And I wul þat þe sai&dtail; graunte of þe sai&dtail; annuite be graunte&dtail; witℏ clause of destresse paieable atte too termes, þat is to say, at Esterne and

Furthermore my wi&llbar; is, þat if Robert my son be a prest in time to come, seyng þat þanne my lande þat is tayle&dtail; to him in Leicestre, Whytewe&llbar; Whitwell in the Hundred of Alstoe. R. shulde descende to þe sai&dtail; Iames, þat þanne þe remaindre of Braceby a-fore sai&dtail; be til William my sone after þe decesse of his mode&rtail; Cecile; or if she take hire an husbon&dtail;, as hit is rehersyd a-fore.  More-oue&rtail; my wi&llbar; is, þat if my sai&dtail; so&nmacr; Robert be here-afti&rtail; prest, as hit is sai&dtail; before, þanne wul I, if he haf any benefice of holychirche or prebende, þat þanne þe astate þat I ordeigne&dtail; þat ioint feffe&yogh; of my londes and tenementes þat I bought of Richar&dtail; Oxende&nmacr; of Okeham, and also of my burgage þe whicℏ I bought of Richard Mylnere in þe Newgate of Okeham, and my ioint feffe&yogh; of my landes and tenementes in Masthorpe, shulde haf made to Robert my sone for þe terme of his moder lif in sucℏ manere and forme as hit is declare&dtail; in my forme&rtail; wi&llbar;, þat þanne þay sha&llbar; make astate of þe sai&dtail; londes and tenementes to my sai&dtail; sone William in sucℏ manere and fourme as þei shulle haue made to my sai&dtail; sone Robert, wiþ þe remaindre as hit is in my former wille declare&dtail;.  In witnes of whicℏ þis my writyn>ail; of myn own hon&dtail;, I haue annexe&dtail; þis my wille witℏ my testament and former wille, vnder my seal of myn armes, affermyn>ail; my sai&dtail; testament and former wille except þat what, that which. is chaunged in þis my last wille.  writen at Okeham þe Fryday a-fore þe fest of þe aposteles, Seint Simon and Iude, Oct. 28. þe &yogh;ere of oure lor&dtail; a þousan&dtail; foure hundre&dtail; and xxv. and þe &yogh;ere of þe reigne of King Herry þe sext after þe conquest, þe fourte.  And I prey my feffe&yogh; þat alle þese astatys, by þe avys of a wel lerne&dtail; man of þe lawe, of my cost, to be paied by myn Executours.  Almyghty god make good ende!  Amen. text.22:
WILLIAM NEWLAND, OF LONDON AND NORMANDY, 1425. [Going on a Journey.  Pilgrims to be sent to Rome, Jerusalem, Canterbury, St. Michael's Mount, and St. James's of Compostella, for Testator's soul, and Priests to sing for it.  Gifts of gilt and silver Cups and Goblets, Bed, and Money.  Gifts to Parson and Clerk of St. Thomas's, London, and Prisoners and Poor.  Goods for Testator's soul.] (More, 3 Commissary Court of London, lf. 170 bk.) Brigide. T. Willelmi Newland. Habent acquietanciam. [ In margin. ] St. Bridget's, or St. Bride's, Fleet St., in Faringdon Ward Without. I, William Newlan&dtail;, wol þat al men know þat þis here-vnder writen ys my last wi&llbar;, what þat euer god ordene for me in my Iorneye.  First, for to dispose my goodis: þe goodis that be in a paire of trussing cofres in the kepyng of Thomas Brou&ntail;, y wol þat a man be founden þerwith to go to Rome and to Ierusalem, and to haue þer-of for his costes and labour l mar&ctee; Fifty marks, £32 14 s . 4 d .: over £300 in present money. ; a-noþer for to go fro the Swer&dtail; in Fletstrete vn-to Caunterbury, barefot, x s'; and a-noþer for to ride or go vn-to seynt Miche&llbar; mount That in Cornwall, not that in Britany, as only 20 s . is allowd. xx s'; and a-noþer to seynt Iames in Galis St. James's of Compostella, in Galicia, Spain. C s'; and for v prestis for to synge at chircℏ of seint Thomas of Postlis The Church of St. Thomas the Apostle was in ' Knight riders street .. by Wring-wren lane , a proper Church, and in the yeere 1629. well repaired and finely garnished.'— Stow's Survey of London , ed. 1633, p. 258, col. 2. It was burnt in the Great Fire of 1666, and not rebuilt.  The parish was joind to St. Mary Aldermary, Bow Lane, Watling St. a hool yere, l mar&ctee; Fifty marks, £32 14 s . 4 d .: over £300 in present money. ; and for oþer v prestis the next yere suyng in þe same place, l mar&ctee; Fifty marks, £32 14 s . 4 d .: over £300 in present money. .  And y wi&llbar; þat sir Thomas Fawkys haue two gilt cuppis couered, and ij pecis of siluer. and also it is my will þat Elianor of Coto&ntail; There's a Coton 2 miles N. of Cambridge, and another near Rugby, in Warwickshire. haue C mar&ctee; to her mariage, and a browded bed wiþ þe costures þerto, and a cup of Siluer and ij gobelettis.  also y wol þat Thomas Pounce haue x mar&ctee;.  also y wol þat Thomas Brou&ntail; and his wyff haue viij 









 mar&ctee;.  Also y wol þat Ioh&ntail; of Merbury Merbury is not in Walker's Gazetteer . haue x mar&ctee;.  also y wol þat þe persone of seynt Thomas apostolis haue xiij s' iiij &dtail;, and þe clerk vj s' viij &dtail;.  also y wol þat xl mar&ctee; be delid to prisoners and to pore folkys.  also þe remenant of my harneys and oþer goodis, y wi&llbar; þat it be disposed for my sowle, and for a&llbar; þe saules þer euer y had ony good of: and þis y yeue in charge, wiþ witte and good mende, to myn executours, as þey wol answere a-for god, to be treuly disposed as it ys a-boue writen.  and herevpo&ntail; y make myn Executours, Thomas Fawkes a-fore writen, and Elianor of Coto&ntail;, Thomas Pounce & Thomas Brou&ntail;.  Writen þe xx day of Decembre in Londo&ntail; be me William Newland.  And y wol þat al my rentis and goodis in Normandie be disposed be William Faukeswe&llbar; and be Pers Gely, þe half for to be don for my sowle, and þe oþer half y &yogh;eue hem frely for to do trewly for me.  and her-to y set þe seale of my Armes to witnesse. Probatum fuit hoc testamentum coram nobis Dauid Price, vicario Reuerendi in christo patris & domini Willelmi, dei gratia Londonie Episcopi, in spiritualibus generali, xv kalendarum Augusti, anno domini millesimo cccc mo xxvj to , Et per nos legitime pronunciatum pro eodem.  Et commissa est administracio omnium bonorum presens testamentum concernencium, infra iurisdiccionem Londonie existencium, Elianore of so. Coto&ntail;, Thome Pounce & Thome Brou&ntail; executoribus superius nominatis, iuratis primitus in forma iuris, & admissis per eosdem, facultate committenda administracionem huiusmodi Thome Faukys, executori superius nominato, cum venerit, & eandem subire voluerit, nobis specialiter reseruata.  In cuius rei testimonium, sigillum quo in huiusmodi officio vicariatus vtimur, presentibus apposuimus.  Datum Londonie, die & anno domini supradictis.
text.23: WILLIAM DAVY, FISHMONGER, LONDON, 1426. [To be buried in St. Clement's, East-Cheep.  Gifts to the Works, Parson and Clerk of the Church, and other Priests.  Small bequests to Brother, Sister, and friends.  Residue for Testator's Soul.] (More, 3 Commissary Court of London, lf. 228.) C[lement] Est[chepe]. Testamentum Willelmi Davy.  Habent acquietanciam. [ In margin. ] The Executors have paid their dues to the Court. In þe name of god, amen.  In the xxvij day of nouember, The &yogh;ere of ou&rtail; lord M. CCCC mo xxvj, I. William Dauy, Fyscℏmongere and Citezyn of Londo&nmacr;, In hool mynde, make and ordeyne my Testament in this maner: Ferst I be-quethe my sowle to al-myghty god and to al þe seyntis, my body to be beryed in þe Cherche-&yogh;erd of seynt Clementis be syde Est chepe This is a small Church, void of Monuments, other than of Francis Barnam , Alderman, who deceased 1575, and of Benedict Barnam his sonne, Alderman also 1598.— Stow's Survey , 1633, p. 235, col. 1. This Church was repaired and beautified at the cost and charge of the Parishioners, in the yeere of our Lord God, 1632.— ib . p. 832, col. 1 .  Burnt in the Great Fire, 1666; rebuilt by Wren. . Al-so I be-quethe to the werkes of the forseyd cherche, xl s'.  Al-so I be-quethe to the persone of the sayde cherche, xiij s' iiij &dtail;.  Also I be-quethe to the mayster clerke iij s' iiij &dtail;.  Also I be-quethe sere Wil&yogh;am Podo&ntail;, iij s'. iiij &dtail;.  Also I be-quethe sere Ioh&nmacr; Buk, iij s' iiij &dtail;.  Also I wele that euery prest that is at my dyrige and at messe, haue vj &dtail;.  Also I be-quethe Margrete Schiplake, xl s'.  Al-so I be-quetℏ Waket, prentys with Schiplake, vj s' viij &dtail;.  Also I be-quethe Ioh&nmacr; Davy my brotℏer xl. s'.  Also I be-quethe Margery my siste&rtail;, xx s'.  And þe residue of al my godys after my testament is fulfyllyd and my dettys payd, they be disposyd for my soule after the disposicion of my executour. and to this I make and ordeyne William Schiplake, Barbour, myn executour; and I be-quetne the same William xl s'; Al-so &yogh;eue hym with-owte that, for hese laboure, vj s' viij &dtail;.  Item I be-quethe Ioℏ&nmacr; Lowesley vj s' viij &dtail;.  Wittenessis, sere Andrewe Norwiche, persone, Probably the Parson drew up the Will.  See the Common Form for Willsdrawn by Parsons when applied to, in Bp. Lacy's Liber Pontificalis , cited in the Notes , on a Widow's Vow of Chastity.  This Form included gifts to the Church, Parson, Clerk, &c. and Thomas Rokewode, clerk. Probatum est & &ctee;. ije nonarum Decembris, anno domini supradicto, coram Roberto Derffel&dtail; &c &ctee;.  Et commissa est &&ctee; Willelmo Schiplake, executori supradicto.  Et admissum per eundem, iurato primitus in forma iuris.

Huius autem testamenti mei, Robertum de Teye, Armigerum, Iohannem Basset predictum, Iohannem Whetley, ciuem ciuitatis Londonie, & Philippum Dene, ordino, facio et constituo Executores meos.  þat þay be sol&dtail; by myn Executours to as hie prys as hit may, withoute fraude or male engyne, and þe money therof resceyue&dtail;, be dispende&dtail; for my soule, after þe discrecioun of myn Executours. Also I wo&llbar; þat myn obite be kept &YOGH;erly atte Bikenacre, Bradwe&llbar;, and Canwedo&nmacr;, Canewdon near Rochford.—J. H. Round. and þat þay haue to þe werkes of Canwedo&nmacr; chircℏ, x markes.  Also I wo&llbar; þat amon>ail; þe powremen of Richefordhundre&dtail;, Rochford Hundred. Dunchehundre&dtail;, Dengey Hundred.—J. H. Round. and Chelmysfor&dtail; hundre&dtail;, be dele&dtail; by myn Executours breed and herynge to þe valu of xx marces durin>ail; þe terme of x &yogh;ere.  Essexie A line of contraction is over the 'x', whether to mark a Latin genitive or not (Thomas of Essex), I can't say. wot where is, be delyuere&dtail; to myn Executours forto dispende þe goudes þat is ther-yn, for my soule, and þat þe same Thomas Essexie A line of contraction is over the 'x', whether to mark a Latin genitive or not (Thomas of Essex), I can't say. haue v marces in honde, and also xx s' terme of his lyf. Also I wo&llbar; þat Rolf Baynar&dtail; and Darsy, if þay be witholde truly witℏ &yogh;ow, þat euery haue xl. s'.  Also I wo&llbar; þat Rober&dtail; of Teye, myn Executour, haue for his labour, xxx &lbar;i; Ioh&ntail; Basset of Chishu&llbar;, xx &lbar;i; Ioh&nmacr; Whetley, xx &lbar;i; Phelippe Dene, for he is pore, xx &lbar;i; And also to William Babyngto&nmacr;, forto be good helpe&rtail; and counceillou&rtail; to myn Executours in a&llbar; matiers of lawe touchin>ail; hem and þe execucion of my testament and last wi&llbar;, xx marces.  Also I wo&llbar; þat sire Ioℏn, my preest, haue xx s', and a gowne of my weryn>ail;. Also I wo&llbar; þat Wi&llbar; my man haue xx s'.  And I wo&llbar; and pray &yogh;ow þat Phelippe be kept on seruice stille, and haue as goud wages as he hadde of me be-forne durin>ail; þe terme of ij. &yogh;ere.  Also I wo&llbar; þat my seruaunttes be rewarde&dtail; after &yogh;oure discrecioun.  Also I praye my feffours þat þay wolde enfeffe Philippe Dene on .vj. marces of rente durin>ail; þe terme of his li&ftee;, where þat he wo&llbar; chese of a&llbar; my londes best reysi&dtail;.  And also I praye, and in goddisbyhalf require, þat alle þe feffes þat ben enfeffyd in my londes, þat in what tyme þat þay ben duly require&dtail; by myn Executours to make a-state to any person, þat þay perfourme 


 hit in discharge of my soule, as þey wo&llbar; onswere a-fore god.  Also I pray my feffours þat þay wold suffer myn Executours to selle Stanlehalle, and to enfeffe what man þat euer myn Executours require hem to.  Also .I. wo&llbar; þat my Maners of Welsham and Brethenham Brettenham, Suffolk, N. W. of Bilston. be sol&dtail; by myn Executours, and þe money þerof be dispose&dtail; by myn Executours.  Also I wo&llbar; þat my Childre&nmacr; haue C &lbar;i, and þat þey, and þer goudes þat longetℏ to ham, be gouerned atte a&llbar; tymes by þe discrecion of myn Executours.  And þat a&llbar; þe reuenuys and profitys comyn>ail; of my londes þat ben not assigne&dtail; by my last wi&llbar; and testament for to be sol&dtail; ouer þe sustenaunce of þe sei&dtail; childrun, be disposi&dtail; and dispendi&dtail; for my soule by þe discrecion of myn Executours.
